instruction: Tell me about File Naming Best Practices
output: File names should be precise as NTFS file name size has a limit of 255 characters. This is a hard limit of the system that the Storage/Compute platform uses. Any files to be transferred to Storage/Compute need to be created following this limit or they cannot be transferred.

instruction: How do I get started with RIS Services?
output: It is assumed that users will be research faculty and staff and have Wash U WUSTL Key IDs, have access to Wash U IT Networks, and have access to a departmental WorkDay Cost Center Number. With these as pre-requisites, one can request new services by creating a Service Desk Request via the RIS Service Desk.

instruction: Can I access RIS compute services off campus?
output: Yes, however you will need to use a VPN to access compute1. Head over to https://it.wustl.edu/items/connect/ for further instructions.

instruction: How do I login to RIS compute services?
output: The compute service uses the SSH protocol to one of several numbered access points with names like compute1-client-N, where N is a number. Here is an example of connecting to client-1: ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: A subscription tier is associated with a number of resources that are guaranteed for use based on the tier.

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: A condo queue is a queue associated with a purchased condo. More information about condos can be found here: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/compute/compute-condo/

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: The general queue runs batch jobs much like the traditional HPC setting. They run in the background in the queue system. The general queue also makes use of cache system, which you can learn more about here. Jobs in the general queue can run for up to 28 days.

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: The general-interactive queue runs jobs interactively so that you can interact directly with them or watch a job. The general-interactive queue does not use the cache system and instead interfaces with the Storage Platform directly. Jobs in the general-interactive queue can run for up to 24 hours.

instruction: How do I view active jobs on RIS compute1?

instruction: Can I assign priority to the execution of my jobs on RIS Compute?
output: Yes. Use the -sp flag to set a numeric priority to the execution of your jobs. You can modify the priority of jobs in a pending state by using bmod -sp.

instruction: Can I prioritize the execution of my jobs on RIS Compute?
output: Yes. Use the -sp flag to set a numeric priority to the execution of your jobs. You can modify the priority of jobs in a pending state by using bmod -sp.

instruction: I have a large amount of jobs on RIS compute that are similar. How can I manage them?
output: When submitting a lot of similar jobs, they should submitted as an array. This allows you to easily submit and manage all of the jobs as a single entity. A single LSF bsub command is used to submit and can be altered with a single command as well. Each job in the array can also be accessed and modified individually if necessary.

instruction: I have a large quantity of tasks on RIS compute that are alike. How can I effective handle them?

A single LSF bsub command is used to submit and can be altered with a single command as well. Each job in the array can also be accessed and modified individually if necessary.

instruction: How do I submit jobs on RIS Compute as an array?
output: To submit one thousand jobs as a single job array called myArray, you would issue the following command: bsub -J 'myArray[1-1000]' SCRIPT.

instruction: How do I submit jobs on RIS Compute as an array?
output: To submit one thousand jobs as a single job array called myArray, you would issue the following command: bsub -J 'myArray[1-1000]' SCRIPT.

instruction: Kindly give me step-by-step directions on submitting jobs as an array on RIS Compute.
output: To submit one thousand jobs as a single job array called myArray, you would issue the following command: bsub -J 'myArray[1-1000]' SCRIPT.

instruction: How do I cancel a running job on RIS Compute?
output: Use the bkill command, along with the job ID. Running bkill 0 kills all of your jobs.

instruction: How do I cancel a running job on RIS Compute?
output: Use the bkill command, along with the job ID. Running bkill 0 kills all of your jobs.

output: Use the bkill command, along with the job ID. Running bkill 0 kills all of your jobs.

instruction: Can you provide instructions on how to terminate a job that is currently in progress on RIS Compute?
output: Use the bkill command, along with the job ID. Running bkill 0 kills all of your jobs.

instruction: I need to know the steps to cancel a job that is currently running on RIS Compute.
output: Use the bkill command, along with the job ID. Running bkill 0 kills all of your jobs.

instruction: How do I pause a running job on RIS Compute?
output: Jobs can be stopped using bstop and later resumed with bresume.

instruction: Does RIS offer Docker containers or a repository for them?
output: RIS offers RIS hosted and controlled Docker images. You can find them here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-supported-containers.html /n RIS also offers a list of vetted applications where we do not control the Docker image nor host it. You can find that list here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/compute/recipes/ris-vetted-compute-apps.html

instruction: Can RIS help me debug my software?
output: We strive to provide help with software debugging and support to the best of our abilities and time. With that being said, there may be times when we cannot solve an issue related to a specific piece of software or script that is not supported by RIS. In those cases, we will attempt to provide a solution to the problem, but we cannot guarantee that the solution will be successful.

instruction: What are some ways I can access data in the RIS storage service?
output: At this time, you can access storage service via SMB mounts from MacOS, Linux, and Windows, Globus Data Transfer endpoints, and POSIX filesystem access within RIS compute.

instruction: How do I change my password for RIS compute?
output: Since RIS Compute Services uses WUSTL Key credentials you must change your password for that. Wash U IT has documentation on resetting WUSTL Key passwords: https://connect.wustl.edu/selfservice/SECURE/ChangePassword.aspx

instruction: What does it mean to have a RIS Compute Condo(minium)
output: Faculty members may purchase dedicated hardware for their labs to form what we refer to as a “condominium”. In this model, a “condo” is formed out of a set of hardware that we put into a Host Group. Then we create a pair of Queues named after the Lab, eg labname and labname-interactive. Then we create an AD group named compute-labname and populate it with Users. That group then gets priority access to that lab.

instruction: How much space is in my RIS Compute $HOME directory?
output: $HOME directories are limited to 10GB. If you wish to observe your quota, you can use the following command: mmlsquota --block-size auto -u wustlkey cache1-fs1:home1

instruction: Why is RIS Compute $HOME limited to 10G? Can I have more?
output: User $HOME directories are intended to allow space for users to make use of the compute cluster, with the knowledge that the Storage Cluster is where data and software will be stored. This is accessed via /storage1, and the Scratch Cluster is accessed via /scratch1. The $HOME directory is NOT backed up and important data should NOT be stored here. Anything you wish to be backed up should be placed in /storage1, this includes scripts.

instruction: How do I see what is using up all of my RIS Compute $HOME space?
output: You can use the following command to list out the top 10 (or any number if you replace the 10) files or directories using the most space in your $HOME directory. Make sure the following command is run from your $HOME directory: du -hsx .[^.]* * 2>/dev/null | sort -rh | head -10

instruction: Why am I getting a Disk I/O error on RIS?
output: This error typically refers to the ability of the job to write a file to a directory. The most common source of the error is a user’s home directory being full. If you encounter this error, please follow the steps below. /nUse the methods described in the home directory space section section to determine if the home directory is at cap. /nRemove or move files from the home directory to reduce usage. /nAttempt to run the job again. /nIf the problem persists, submit a ticket to the service desk: https://ris.wustl.edu/support/service-desk/

instruction: How do I share files in my storage with colleagues using RIS services?
output: You can request access be granted to your colleagues through our ticketing system: https://jira.wustl.edu/servicedesk/customer/portal/2/group/7. You can also use collections within Globus to share specific folders or files with colleagues. This method is the suggested method when it comes to colleagues outside of WashU. You can find more information about using this feature here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/storage/globus.html

instruction: Why should I use Open On Demand to access RIS compute?
output: Here are a few reasons why Open On Demand is beneficial. /nUsers can use a web browser to access the RIS Compute Platform. /nUsers can use any number of supported applications or incorporate their own. /nUsers can navigate the RIS Compute Platform and their computing needs in a GUI instead of via the command line.

instruction: How do I group jobs together on RIS Compute?
output: Create a job group with a limit of N running jobs: bgadd -L N /${compute_username}/${group_name}

instruction: What is an LSF compute group?
output: A compute group is required for launching a job. RIS mediates access to services by compute groups, and you will be unable to submit a job if you are not part of one. You can find out what groups you are in by running: groups.

instruction: I am not sure how to run a job on RIS compute. Can you give me an example?
output: After you connect to the compute1 environment, launching the following job will run the date command using an alpine docker image: bsub -Is -q general-interactive -a 'docker(alpine)' date

instruction: I am unsure how to operate a job on RIS compute, could you provide me with an example?
output: After you connect to the compute1 environment, launching the following job will run the date command using an alpine docker image: bsub -Is -q general-interactive -a 'docker(alpine)' date
